critique: This executive order aims to address environmental justice, focusing on the disproportionate impact of environmental hazards on minority and low-income populations. It directs federal agencies to incorporate environmental justice into their missions, develop strategies, and collect data. It also emphasizes public participation and access to information. The order does not directly address immigration, so that axis should be neutral. It creates an interagency working group and requires agencies to develop strategies and report on their progress, suggesting an expansion of federal oversight and potentially executive power to ensure compliance. The order promotes social inclusion by focusing on minority and low-income populations. It also leans towards government intervention in economic regulation by directing agencies to address environmental effects. The ideological tilt is liberal, given the focus on social justice and environmental protection. The order does not seem to directly impact federalism. Finally, the order seems to strike a balance between national security and civil liberties, as it does not directly address either.
